tool.name: LogisticRegression
tool.description: : Wrapper of the scikit-learn LogisticRegression method.

param.name: input_dataset_path
param.label: input CSV file
param.help: Path to the input dataset. Format: [input].csv

param.name: outname_output_model_path
param.label: output PKL name
param.help: Path to the output model file Format: [output].pkl

param.name: outname_output_test_table_path
param.label: output CSV name
param.help: Path to the test table file Format: [output].csv

param.name: outname_output_plot_path
param.label: output PNG name
param.help: Path to the statistics plot. If target is binary it shows confusion matrix, distributions of the predicted probabilities of both classes and ROC curve. If target is non-binary it shows confusion matrix Format: [output].png

param.name: sele
param.label: Take tool settings:
param.help: Select where tool settings are to be read from

param.name: properties
param.label: Configuration file
param.help: File containing tool settings. See below for the syntax

param.name: jsonstr
param.label: JSON string
param.help: JSON string containing tool settings. See below for the syntax

param.name: independent_vars
param.label: independent_vars
param.help: Independent variables you want to train from your dataset. You can specify either a list of columns names from your input dataset, a list of columns indexes or a range of columns indexes. Formats: { "columns": ["column1", "column2"] } or { "indexes": [0, 2, 3, 10, 11, 17] } or { "range": [[0, 20], [50, 102]] }. In case of mulitple formats, the first one will be picked. (Json)

param.name: target
param.label: target
param.help: Dependent variable you want to predict from your dataset. You can specify either a column name or a column index. Formats: { "column": "column3" } or { "index": 21 }. In case of mulitple formats, the first one will be picked. (Json)

param.name: weight
param.label: weight
param.help: Weight variable from your dataset. You can specify either a column name or a column index. Formats: { "column": "column3" } or { "index": 21 }. In case of mulitple formats, the first one will be picked. (Json)

param.name: solver
param.label: solver
param.option: newton-cg - Recall the motivation for gradient descent step at x: we minimize the quadratic function
lbfgs - It's analogue of the Newton's Method but here the Hessian matrix is approximated using updates specified by gradient evaluations
liblinear - It's a linear classification that supports logistic regression and linear support vector machines
sag - SAG method optimizes the sum of a finite number of smooth convex functions
saga - It's a variant of SAG that also supports the non-smooth penalty=l1 option

param.name: c_parameter
param.label: c_parameter
param.help: Inverse of regularization strength; must be a positive float. Smaller values specify stronger regularization.

param.name: normalize_cm
param.label: normalize_cm
param.help: Whether or not to normalize the confusion matrix.

param.name: random_state_method
param.label: random_state_method
param.help: Controls the randomness of the estimator.

param.name: random_state_train_test
param.label: random_state_train_test
param.help: Controls the shuffling applied to the data before applying the split.

param.name: test_size
param.label: test_size
param.help: Represents the proportion of the dataset to include in the test split. It should be between 0.0 and 1.0.

param.name: scale
param.label: scale
param.help: Whether or not to scale the input dataset.
